title: Ph. D. Web App documentation
text:
1 Introduction to the application
The Ph.D. TITLE web application aims to be a Proof of Concept of a potential future tool that assesses marine economic activities affection to habitats and ecosystem service delivery. This information is crucial for informed decission-making and can promote better-designed Marine Spatial Plans (MSPs) that minimize activity impact and maximize ecosystem service delivery, including future climate change effects into habitat distributions and ecosystem service provision.
Ph.D. TITLE web application is divided into five main sections: (1) management scenarios; (2) saltmarsh evolution; (3) physical accounts; (4) EVA overscale; and (5) fish stocks. In all cases, model codes used to obtain the results of Ph.D Title are available in ./app/models and will be further explained in the corresponging sections.
crumbs: 1  Ph.D. TITLE - Web App Documentation

title: Ph. D. Web App documentation
text:
1.1 About this Documentation
Transparency and reproducibility are an integral part of the research. Thus, here you will find all the details of the approaches and decisions taken in this work. This is a complement to the available scientific articles, thesis and codes. Public data sources and/or data obtained in the thesis are available at fake data and results could be found in results. In case some desired results are not available, please contact: benat.egidazu@bc3research.org. However, data sources also include other author contributions, in that case you may need to contact those authors for specific datasets.
crumbs: 1  Ph.D. TITLE - Web App Documentation

title: 2  Management Scenarios
text:
Management Scenarios tab gives you the option to explore the potential affection of a set of marine economic activities (i.e. wind farms, aquaculture plants, vessel routes and/or defence/military areas) in the study areas where the Ph.D. studies have been carried out. In this sense, you can select Santander Coast, North Sea, Irish Sea, Urdaibai Estuary and Cadiz Bay study areas. The affection in this Proof of Concept is based on the Physical Accounts studies and the Saltmarsh Evolution studies. Thus, it is worth noting that in some study areas you could explore the potential affection of EUNIS habitats and/or saltmarsh and mudflat current affection and under a set of climate change scenarios. The following table is a summary of the available affection in each study area:
